Using ComplementDNASeq

Source: vignettes/using-complementdnaseq.Rmd
using-complementdnaseq.Rmd

Introduction

ComplementDNASeq provides a simple utility to compute the reverse complement of DNA sequences. This vignette walks through typical usage patterns and discusses how the package validates input.

Installation

The package can be installed from GitHub using remotes:

# install.packages("remotes")
remotes::install_github("CEDRICHK/ComplementDNASeq")

Basic usage

Load the package and call reverse_complement() with a DNA sequence composed of A, C, G, and T.

library(ComplementDNASeq)
reverse_complement("GATTACA")
#> [1] "TGTAATC"

The function returns the reverse complement sequence, flipping the order and swapping each nucleotide with its complement (A ↔︎ T, C ↔︎ G).

Handling invalid input

If the input contains characters other than the standard nucleotides, the function raises an error to prevent ambiguous results.

reverse_complement("GATUACA")
#> Error in reverse_complement("GATUACA"): `seq` may only contain the characters A, C, G, and T.

Missing values are propagated unchanged so that the function can be safely used on vectors that may contain NA entries.

reverse_complement(NA_character_)
#> [1] NA

Working with vectors

reverse_complement() operates on a single sequence at a time. When you have a vector of sequences, combine it with vectorised helpers such as vapply().

seqs <- c("ACTG", "TTTT", "CGCG")
vapply(seqs, reverse_complement, character(1))
#>   ACTG   TTTT   CGCG 
#> "CAGT" "AAAA" "CGCG"

The helper ensures each element is processed individually while returning a character vector of matching length.
